chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: Hello, how are you all?  Welcome to Chai and Code, our unique YouTube channel  If you haven't subscribed to our channel yet, then please do it now  Tell your friends to subscribe to our channel so that we can bring more interesting videos  We are running a Jango series right now

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: The rest of the videos are on a different channel  This video is a part of the Jango series  In the last video, we saw how Jango is set up  We used UV, which is quite modern, popular and fast  We saw about the file structure, how the settings are, the URL files and many more

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: In this video, we will see how the flow structure of Jango is so that you don't face any problems in the application  No matter how complex the application is, the flow of Jango is exactly the same  I have made a diagram for you, we will understand it slowly  After that, we will implement the diagram in the code so that we can understand the flow and structure  It's a fun video, you will enjoy it

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: I am taking the target of 300 comments, hopefully you will complete it as soon as possible  Let's share the screen and discuss the diagram first  Because it is a very fun diagram  We will not see this diagram completely, we will see it one by one  I will put it aside so that you don't face any problem

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: Jango is a web framework  All the web frameworks use a tech stack under the hood  So that they can find out about the request, response, browser, etc.  By default, Python can't find out which request you have, which response you have  There are some event triggers that do this work behind the scenes

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: We have a very simple flow, Jango doesn't have a thousand things  It's just a simple flow, 3 or 4 things are involved in it  That's it, and they are always involved  That's why Jango is so reliable and fast  This is your user

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: They need a request response model  That means they have a website, either they want to log in to it or see a tweet or something like that  So they fired their browser and sent a request directly  Now this request goes to a website  Now behind the scenes, there is Nginx, Kadi, any server running on the website

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: We don't have anything to do with it  When we deploy, we will see that thing  So this request goes to Jango  Now what Jango does is, it finds out which resource you want to access from where you got the request  Like you accessed the slash login, slash register, slash tweet, slash one, whatever the tweet ID is, you accessed it

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: On that basis, Jango has an internal URL resolver  This URL resolver doesn't do anything, it just resolves the URL  Whether you want to log in or slash where you want to go  You never come to this URL resolver, 99% chance that you will never see it or access it  This core is inbuilt in Jango

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: We don't see this file, nor do we have access to it by default  We get it if we want, but we don't come to it  This URL resolver finally accesses another file, which is called URL.py  So we have this request from here  The request says, resolve the URL and see where it should go

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: Then we get the URL.py file  Now this URL.py file, we saw here  The way we had slash admin, we can have more resolvers of URL  But it's not necessary that you always come to this URL.py, this main file  Many times this URL file redirects you to another

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: Like I told you, Jango can have multiple small apps  So this URL.py can further redirect you to another URL file  Consider it as a modular code, not a big deal  So it's possible that you came here, it's possible that URL.py sent you directly here  Now this URL.py file sends you to a file called views.py

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: Now this views.py file is not visible anywhere  But it's not that it doesn't exist, we can make it if we want  So I have Jango, remember where I am, what is my level, see that  Here I am in my project, this is my complete directory  Project is in the directory

chunks.text: I opened this, I will make a new file here so that we can understand it  I made this views.py, it's name is views only  It can't be view, it can't be my view, it can't be your view, it can't be Chai view  Okay, we went to the views.py file  So what does views.py file do?

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: This is your main controller, main logic where it will be written  It's possible that you have to send a response directly, welcome to Jango  Or it's possible that you have to send via models.py  We don't have the models file now, it will eventually come  Through this, we can contact DB

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: Or your views.py file can also contact DB  It has a complete option, we have ORMs in Jango, we will discuss them too  But now the main thing is that the views.py file has the access to take something from the database  To save something in it, all our logic is written here  Once you have written the logic, then you have to send a response to the front end

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: And this response comes straight to Jango  And Jango sends this response, that's it  And sometimes it uses some templates, which we will do too  And via template it sends you the response  So this is a complete complex architecture that is behind the scenes in Jango

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: Now if I want to make a small architecture of this  How will we do this, it's very easy  You have a user, this is our user  This user sent a request, so suppose we got a request  Now where will this request go, it will go to the urls.py file

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: Who will the urls.py file call, it will call the views  That's it, so let's make arrows on it  The user sent a request, the request went to our url.py  And the url.py sent it to the views  What will the views do, it will send a response to the url

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: So it came back to the url  We will not accept the url, it will send you a response  So we will send it here and take a simple response  Here, the response is sent to you, that's it  And this is your complete Jango

chunks.title: Templates and errors in Django
chunks.text: That's it, in 4 lines, our Jango is complete  You get a request, the request hits the urls.py  The urls.py can call the views  Views are different ways of how it will send you a response  It may send a query from the database, it may send a direct response

text: Hello, how are you all? Welcome to Chai and Code, our unique YouTube channel If you haven't subscribed to our channel yet, then please do it now Tell your friends to subscribe to our channel so that we can bring more interesting videos We are running a Jango series right now The rest of the videos are on a different channel This video is a part of the Jango series In the last video, we saw how Jango is set up We used UV, which is quite modern, popular and fast We saw about the file structure, how the settings are, the URL files and many more In this video, we will see how the flow structure of Jango is so that you don't face any problems in the application No matter how complex the application is, the flow of Jango is exactly the same I have made a diagram for you, we will understand it slowly After that, we will implement the diagram in the code so that we can understand the flow and structure It's a fun video, you will enjoy it I am taking the target of 300 comments, hopefully you will complete it as soon as possible Let's share the screen and discuss the diagram first Because it is a very fun diagram We will not see this diagram completely, we will see it one by one I will put it aside so that you don't face any problem Jango is a web framework All the web frameworks use a tech stack under the hood So that they can find out about the request, response, browser, etc. By default, Python can't find out which request you have, which response you have There are some event triggers that do this work behind the scenes We have a very simple flow, Jango doesn't have a thousand things It's just a simple flow, 3 or 4 things are involved in it That's it, and they are always involved That's why Jango is so reliable and fast This is your user They need a request response model That means they have a website, either they want to log in to it or see a tweet or something like that So they fired their browser and sent a request directly Now this request goes to a website Now behind the scenes, there is Nginx, Kadi, any server running on the website We don't have anything to do with it When we deploy, we will see that thing So this request goes to Jango Now what Jango does is, it finds out which resource you want to access from where you got the request Like you accessed the slash login, slash register, slash tweet, slash one, whatever the tweet ID is, you accessed it On that basis, Jango has an internal URL resolver This URL resolver doesn't do anything, it just resolves the URL Whether you want to log in or slash where you want to go You never come to this URL resolver, 99% chance that you will never see it or access it This core is inbuilt in Jango We don't see this file, nor do we have access to it by default We get it if we want, but we don't come to it This URL resolver finally accesses another file, which is called URL.py So we have this request from here The request says, resolve the URL and see where it should go Then we get the URL.py file Now this URL.py file, we saw here The way we had slash admin, we can have more resolvers of URL But it's not necessary that you always come to this URL.py, this main file Many times this URL file redirects you to another Like I told you, Jango can have multiple small apps So this URL.py can further redirect you to another URL file Consider it as a modular code, not a big deal So it's possible that you came here, it's possible that URL.py sent you directly here Now this URL.py file sends you to a file called views.py Now this views.py file is not visible anywhere But it's not that it doesn't exist, we can make it if we want So I have Jango, remember where I am, what is my level, see that Here I am in my project, this is my complete directory Project is in the directory I opened this, I will make a new file here so that we can understand it I made this views.py, it's name is views only It can't be view, it can't be my view, it can't be your view, it can't be Chai view Okay, we went to the views.py file So what does views.py file do? This is your main controller, main logic where it will be written It's possible that you have to send a response directly, welcome to Jango Or it's possible that you have to send via models.py We don't have the models file now, it will eventually come Through this, we can contact DB Or your views.py file can also contact DB It has a complete option, we have ORMs in Jango, we will discuss them too But now the main thing is that the views.py file has the access to take something from the database To save something in it, all our logic is written here Once you have written the logic, then you have to send a response to the front end And this response comes straight to Jango And Jango sends this response, that's it And sometimes it uses some templates, which we will do too And via template it sends you the response So this is a complete complex architecture that is behind the scenes in Jango Now if I want to make a small architecture of this How will we do this, it's very easy You have a user, this is our user This user sent a request, so suppose we got a request Now where will this request go, it will go to the urls.py file Who will the urls.py file call, it will call the views That's it, so let's make arrows on it The user sent a request, the request went to our url.py And the url.py sent it to the views What will the views do, it will send a response to the url So it came back to the url We will not accept the url, it will send you a response So we will send it here and take a simple response Here, the response is sent to you, that's it And this is your complete Jango That's it, in 4 lines, our Jango is complete You get a request, the request hits the urls.py The urls.py can call the views Views are different ways of how it will send you a response It may send a query from the database, it may send a direct response It may send through templates, it may send through something else This is your complete logical structure So if you ever want to understand Jango, if you understand this That's it, nothing else to do This is all the work of Jango And if you want to understand in more detail, then this is the complete structure You may have made a diagram in which you are taking your notes So this is our work Now let's follow this diagram First, we go to this views.py Because here we will write our logic So we write logic, how will we work After that we will go to urls.py Which view to hit on which url And then we will see the request response It's a very basic work So let's go to the code one So we have views.py on the code Look carefully, this is the level of views.py This level has a lot of problems The name is views.py If there is some other name, then the problem comes It's a framework, the name is restricted in the framework Okay, so you understood this Now let's go to write some code So let's write the code It's a very basic python code Hope you know python If you don't know, then you will understand a lot Many people learn Import will come from http response There is also a request Now we are not on request, now we just have to give response So we got this, now you can give response As soon as you get http request or response Means you are ready to take both request and response Compared to if you are coming from any other programming language Then you have to take request, response, etc. In python, you don't have to do this Now we have to make some methods or you can say function So my first function is home You have to add request here So that you know that I have to return this home on a request And after that I said return Now what do you have to return?
